metadata.titleEn: Dataset of soil properties for land surface modeling over China
metadata.description:
The dataset includes soil physical and chemical attributes: pH value, organic matter fraction, cation exchange capacity, root abundance, total nitrogen (N), total phosphorus (P), total potassium (K), alkali-hydrolysable N, available P, available K, exchangeable H+, Al3+, Ca2+, Mg2+, K+ , Na+, horizon thickness, soil profile depth, sand, silt and clay fractions, rock fragment, bulk density, porosity, structure, consistency and soil color. Quality control information (QC) was provided.
The resolution is 30 arc-seconds (about 1 km at the equator). The vertical variation of soil property was captured by eight layers to the depth of 2.3 m (i.e. 0- 0.045, 0.045- 0.091, 0.091- 0.166, 0.166- 0.289, 0.289- 0.493, 0.493- 0.829, 0.829- 1.383 and 1.383- 2.296 m) for convenience of use in the Common Land Model and the Community Land Model (CLM).
1.THSCH.nc: Saturated water content of FCH
2.PSI_S.nc: Saturated capillary potential of FCH
3.LAMBDA.nc: Pore size distribution index of FCH
4.K_SCH.nc: Saturate hydraulic conductivity of FCH
5.THR.nc: Residual moisture content of FGM
6.THSGM.nc: Saturated water content of FGM
7.ALPHA.nc: The inverse of the air-entry value of FGM
8.N.nc: The shape parameter of FGM
9.L.nc: The pore-connectivity parameter of FGM
10.K_SVG.nc: Saturated hydraulic conductivity of FGM
11.TH33.nc: Water content at -33 kPa of suction pressure, or field capacity
12.TH1500.nc: Water content at -1500 kPa of suction pressure, or permanent wilting point

background: As land surface models (LSMs) for use in numerical weather prediction models (NWPs) and Earth system models (ESMs) become more sophisticated, they need more detailed information on physical and chemical properties of soil, including information on how soil properties change with depth in the soil and across geographic areas. The soil datasets now used in global land modeling were derived from the FAO/UNESCO (Food and Agriculture Organization, United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization) world soil map (1:5 million) and limited soil profile data. The development of these data sets used little data from the China national soil surveys in 1950s and later. The soil map data and soil attribute data of the sampled profiles are two source databases for developing the spatial soil property dataset. The soil map is composed of mapping units, and each mapping unit is composed of soil units. Chinese scholars have developed two schemes, the Genetic Soil Classification of China (GSCC) and the Chinese Soil Taxonomy (CST) classification. However, most soil profile information in China has been referenced to the GSCC, which was used in the Second National Soil Survey of China. Soil profiles have commonly been used to assign measured properties to each classification element (soil map unit), i.e. using “taxotransfer rules” that ignore the spatial variability within map units. The Harmonized World Soil Database (HWSD) is a newly released global soil dataset available for land modeling use. It was established by combining existing regional and national updates of soil information, in particular, the Soil Map of China at 1:1 million. The HWSD only incorporates the Soil Map of China, but not the abundant soil profile information. This paper describes the development of the China soil characteristics dataset for use in land models in NWPs/ESMs. This effort is unique in that, for the first time, the China NWPs/ESMs community will have access to a dataset of physical and chemical properties of soil specifically designed for modeling applications.
research objective: This paper describes the development of the China soil characteristics dataset for use in land models in NWPs/ESMs. The aim of this work is to derive a coverage map for soil characteristics based on the legacy soil data of China that can be conveniently used by regional modelers.
challenges: The soil database of China could not be directly used for regional land surface modeling without first dealing with some issues including: Soil particle size distribution is given under the International Society of Soil Science (ISSS) and the Katschinski's schemes. However, most land surface models require soil texture data in the FAO-USDA (United States Department of Agriculture) System. Soil profiles differ from each other in terms of number, sequence, thickness and depth to the top and bottom soil layers. In addition, not all the layers have data for all soil characteristics. About three fourths of the soil profiles have a depth less than 1 meter, and 90% of them have a depth less than 1.5 meters. The soil map provides a horizontal pattern of soil type information but soil profiles provide a vertical variation of soil characteristics at point locations. There is no spatially continuous information of soil properties. Many land surface models require uniform grid cells or raster format, while map units of the 1:1 million soil map of China are defined as polygons in a vector format.
methods: We used the polygon linkage method to derive the spatial distribution of soil properties. The soil type linkage method and the soil polygon linkage method were used to derive the spatial distribution of soil characteristics. The soil type linkage method was accomplished by linking soil map units (soil types) and soil profiles according to taxonomy-based pedotransfer rules. The soil polygon linkage method works by linking a soil polygon with several closest soil profiles that have the same soil type and texture classes as the soil polygon. The linkage procedure, as described by Shangguan et al. [2012], incrementally enlarges the search radius for profiles until the target sample size is reached.
dataset: A comprehensive 30×30 arc-second resolution gridded soil characteristics dataset of China has been developed for use in the land surface modeling. It includes physical and chemical attributes of soils derived from 8,979 soil profiles and the Soil Map of China (1:1,000,000). The dataset includes 28 attributes for 8 vertical layers at the spatial resolution of 30×30 arc-seconds.
findings: Based on this dataset, the estimated storage of soil organic carbon in the upper 1 m of soil is 72.5 Pg, total N is 6.6 Pg, total P is 4.5 Pg, total K is 169.9 Pg, alkali-hydrolysable N is 0.55 Pg, available P is 0.03 Pg, and available K is 0.61 Pg. These estimates are reasonable compared with previous studies. The distributions of soil properties are consistent with common knowledge of Chinese soil scientists and the spatial variations over large areas are well represented. The dataset can be incorporated into land models to better represent the role of soils in hydrological and biogeochemical cycles in China.

Disjunctive.Answer: both the soil type linkage method and the soil polygon linkage method

Concept Completion.Question: What are the primary data collection methods used to derive soil characteristics datasets for land surface modeling?
Concept Completion.Answer: polygon linkage method, soil type linkage method

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to derive spatial soil characteristics from soil maps and profiles in China?
Example.Answer: The polygon linkage method was used to derive the spatial distribution of soil properties by linking soil map units (soil types) with soil profiles according to taxonomy-based pedotransfer rules.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in creating a comprehensive soil characteristics dataset for regional land surface modeling in China?
Example.Answer: One example of a challenge is that soil particle size distribution is given under the International Society of Soil Science (ISSS) and Katschinski's schemes, while most land surface models require soil texture data in the FAO-USDA system.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset developed for understanding the vertical variation of soil characteristics at multiple depths?
Example.Answer: A comprehensive 30×30 arc-second resolution gridded soil characteristics dataset of China was developed, including 28 attributes for 8 vertical layers, facilitating regional modelers in land surface modeling.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific features and attributes included in a soil characteristics dataset for use in land surface modeling?
Feature Specification.Answer: pH value, organic matter content, cation exchange capacity, total nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium levels

Feature Specification.Question: What are the defining challenges in creating a spatially continuous soil properties dataset for regional land surface modeling?
Feature Specification.Answer: varying soil particle size distribution systems, compatibility with land surface models, differences in soil profile depth and characteristics, converting vector-format soil maps into raster format, lack of uniform data across all layers and profiles

Feature Specification.Question: What methods are employed to link soil map units and profiles to derive spatial distributions of soil characteristics?
Feature Specification.Answer: polygon linkage method, soil type linkage method, taxonomy-based pedotransfer rules, search radius incrementally increased

Quantification.Question: How many soil profiles were used to develop a comprehensive soil characteristics dataset?
What is the spatial resolution of the gridded soil characteristics dataset?
How many attributes are included in the vertical layers of the soil characteristics dataset?

Definition.Question: What is the polygon linkage method in the context of deriving spatial distribution of soil properties?
Definition.Answer: The polygon linkage method involves linking a soil polygon with several closest soil profiles that have the same soil type and texture classes as the soil polygon. This approach incrementally enlarges the search radius for profiles until the target sample size is reached, allowing for spatial distribution of soil characteristics.

Definition.Question: What does 'taxotransfer rules' refer to when assigning measured properties to soil map units?
Definition.Answer: 'Taxotransfer rules' refer to the process of assigning measured soil properties to each classification element (soil map unit) based on referenced soil profile information, while often ignoring the spatial variability within those map units.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of the 30×30 arc-second resolution in a soil characteristics dataset?
Definition.Answer: The 30×30 arc-second resolution in a soil characteristics dataset refers to the spatial resolution at which soil properties are gridded. This allows for detailed modeling and representation of soil properties across large geographic areas, facilitating their use in land surface modeling and Earth system models.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences between the polygon linkage method and soil type linkage method for deriving spatial soil properties?
Comparison.Answer: Both the polygon linkage method and the soil type linkage method aim to derive spatial distribution of soil properties by linking soil map units with soil profiles. However, the soil type linkage method uses taxonomy-based pedotransfer rules to link soil types, while the polygon linkage method links soil polygons with the closest soil profiles sharing the same soil type and texture classes, adjusting the search radius to achieve the desired sample size.

Interpretation.Question: What methods can be inferred for linking spatial soil properties to soil profiles when dealing with limited available data?
Interpretation.Answer: The polygon linkage method and the soil type linkage method can be inferred as approaches for linking spatial soil properties to profiles. These methods involve associating soil map units with soil profiles using pedotransfer rules and connecting soil polygons with nearby profiles that share the same soil type and texture classes.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges in data conversion and integration might arise when developing a soil characteristics dataset for regional land surface modeling?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges may include converting soil particle size distribution data from International Society of Soil Science (ISSS) and Katschinski's schemes to the FAO-USDA system, addressing differences in soil profile depth and data completeness, and integrating spatially discrete soil profile information with the horizontal patterns provided by soil maps, which are typically in vector format while models often require raster format.

Interpretation.Question: How might the spatial resolution and vertical layering of a soil dataset be determined to facilitate its use in land surface and Earth system models?
Interpretation.Answer: The spatial resolution can be determined by the need for detailed geographic representation, such as a 30×30 arc-second grid, while vertical layering can be determined by the depth requirements for modeling applications, such as representing soil properties in multiple layers up to 2.3 meters deep to capture vertical variability crucial for land and Earth system models.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for translation of soil particle size distribution data from the International Society of Soil Science (ISSS) and Katschinski's schemes to the FAO-USDA system?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Most land surface models require soil texture data in the FAO-USDA system. This necessitates translating the soil particle size distribution data from the International Society of Soil Science (ISSS) and Katschinski's schemes into a compatible format.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a challenge in creating a spatially continuous soil property dataset from soil profiles and soil maps?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The soil map provides horizontal patterns of soil type information, while soil profiles offer vertical variations of soil characteristics at point locations. Additionally, many land surface models require uniform grid cells or raster format, whereas soil maps are defined as polygons in a vector format, leading to challenges in creating spatially continuous information.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the complexity of linking soil profiles to soil map units for dataset development?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Soil profiles differ in terms of number, sequence, thickness, and depth, and not all layers have data for all soil characteristics. Taxotransfer rules are used to assign measured properties to classification elements, but these rules ignore spatial variability within map units, making the linkage complex.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the consequences of integrating both soil map data and soil profile data on the spatial accuracy of soil property datasets in China?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating both soil map data and soil profile data can enhance the spatial accuracy of soil property datasets by providing a more comprehensive view of both horizontal patterns and vertical variations of soil characteristics. This integration allows for more precise modeling applications in land surface models and can lead to improved representation of soil properties in hydrological and biogeochemical cycles.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the main objective of developing a gridded soil characteristics dataset at a 30×30 arc-second resolution for modeling applications in land surface models?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The aim is to derive a coverage map for soil characteristics based on the legacy soil data of China that can be conveniently used by regional modelers for use in land models in numerical weather prediction models (NWPs) and Earth system models (ESMs).

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to address the challenges in converting soil profile data from the International Society of Soil Science (ISSS) and Katschinski’s schemes to the FAO-USDA system for land surface models?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important because most land surface models require soil texture data in the FAO-USDA system, and the soil database of China could not be directly used for regional land surface modeling without addressing these issues.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of using a linkage method between soil map units and soil profiles in the development of a spatial soil property dataset?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The purpose is to derive the spatial distribution of soil characteristics by linking soil map units (soil types) and soil profiles according to taxonomy-based pedotransfer rules, which helps in creating a comprehensive and spatially continuous dataset for land modeling applications.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can researchers address the challenges of spatial variability and lack of continuous soil property information when developing a soil characteristics dataset?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Researchers tackle these challenges by utilizing the soil polygon linkage method, which links soil polygons with several closest soil profiles sharing the same type and texture classes. This method incrementally enlarges the search radius for profiles until the desired sample size is reached, thus improving spatial continuity and addressing variability.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in linking soil profiles with soil map units to develop a comprehensive soil characteristics dataset?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedure involves using the soil type linkage method and the soil polygon linkage method. The soil type linkage method links soil map units with soil profiles through taxonomy-based pedotransfer rules. The soil polygon linkage method connects a soil polygon with nearby soil profiles sharing the same soil type and texture classes, expanding the search radius as needed to ensure adequate sample size.

Enablement.Question: What resources or methodologies enable the integration of soil profile information into spatially continuous datasets for land modeling applications?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of soil profile information into spatially continuous datasets is enabled by using techniques like the polygon linkage method and the soil type linkage method. These methods involve linking soil map units and soil profiles according to taxonomy-based pedotransfer rules, and linking a soil polygon with several closest soil profiles with the same soil type and texture classes.

Enablement.Question: How do researchers address the challenges of varying soil particle size distribution systems when developing datasets for land surface models?
Enablement.Answer: Researchers address these challenges by converting the soil particle size distribution from schemes like the International Society of Soil Science (ISSS) and Katschinski's schemes to the FAO-USDA System required by most land surface models. This ensures compatibility with modeling requirements.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dataset focusing on soil characteristics in China encounter challenges when representing spatially continuous information of soil properties?
Expectation.Answer: The dataset might encounter challenges because the soil map provides a horizontal pattern of soil type information while soil profiles provide vertical variation at point locations, leading to a lack of spatially continuous information. Additionally, many land surface models require uniform grid cells or raster format, whereas the map units of the 1:1 million soil map of China are defined as polygons in a vector format.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected benefits of using a polygon linkage method in deriving spatial distribution of soil properties, and why might it be preferred over other methods?
Expectation.Answer: The polygon linkage method is expected to provide a more accurate spatial distribution of soil properties by linking soil polygons with several closest soil profiles that have the same soil type and texture classes. This method incrementally enlarges the search radius for profiles until the target sample size is reached, potentially providing a better representation of soil properties over larger spatial scales.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of the polygon linkage method in addressing the challenges posed by variable soil profile depths and spatial variability in soil properties?
Judgmental.Answer: The polygon linkage method is an effective approach as it addresses the challenges of spatial variability and inconsistency in soil profile depths by linking soil map units with soil profiles based on taxonomy and proximity. This method incrementally enlarges the search radius for profiles to achieve the target sample size, thus providing a more comprehensive spatial distribution of soil properties.

Judgmental.Question: What is your opinion on the adequacy of using a 30×30 arc-second resolution for capturing detailed soil characteristics across diverse geographical regions in China?
Judgmental.Answer: Using a 30×30 arc-second resolution is considered adequate for capturing detailed soil characteristics because it allows for a detailed representation of physical and chemical attributes derived from a large number of soil profiles (8,979) and the Soil Map of China. This resolution facilitates the accurate representation of spatial variations over large areas, which aligns with common knowledge of Chinese soil scientists.

Judgmental.Question: To what extent do you believe the challenges of converting soil texture data from the ISSS and Katschinski schemes to the FAO-USDA system impact the utility of a dataset for land surface modeling?
Judgmental.Answer: The conversion of soil texture data from the ISSS and Katschinski schemes to the FAO-USDA system poses a significant challenge, as most land surface models require soil texture data in the FAO-USDA format. This conversion is crucial for ensuring that the dataset is compatible with land surface models, and overcoming this challenge is important for enhancing the utility of the dataset in regional land surface modeling.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how a dataset can provide both horizontal and vertical soil property variations effectively.
Assertion.Answer: The soil map provides horizontal patterns of soil type information, while soil profiles offer vertical variations of soil characteristics at point locations. The polygon linkage method was used to derive spatial distribution, linking soil map units and soil profiles according to taxonomy-based pedotransfer rules.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure how challenges in soil profile data depth can be addressed in land surface modeling.
Assertion.Answer: The challenges include varying soil profile depths, with most being less than 1 meter. These are addressed by linking soil polygons with the closest soil profiles sharing the same type and texture, incrementally enlarging the search radius for profiles until the target sample size is reached.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how spatially continuous soil property information can be derived from discrete soil profile data.
Assertion.Answer: The spatially continuous soil property information is derived using the soil polygon linkage method, which connects soil polygons with several closest soil profiles that match the soil type and texture, thus extrapolating discrete profile data into a comprehensive grid format.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the methodologies used to derive a comprehensive gridded soil characteristics dataset for regional land surface modeling, emphasizing any linkage methods employed.
Request/Directive.Answer: The methodologies used to derive a comprehensive gridded soil characteristics dataset involved the polygon linkage method and the soil type linkage method. The soil type linkage method linked soil map units and soil profiles using taxonomy-based pedotransfer rules. The soil polygon linkage method connected a soil polygon with several closest soil profiles that shared the same soil type and texture classes, incrementally enlarging the search radius for profiles until the target sample size was reached.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the challenges faced in using soil profile data for regional land surface modeling, and how these challenges impact the development of soil datasets.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in using soil profile data include differences in particle size distribution classifications, variations in soil profiles regarding number, sequence, and depth of layers, and the lack of spatially continuous information of soil properties. Most soil profiles have a depth of less than 1.5 meters, which limits available data. These issues impact the development of soil datasets by requiring adjustments to conform to model requirements, such as transforming data into a uniform grid or raster format suitable for land surface models.
